data.text:
Poet. He gained recognition as an early 20th-century Portuguese poet, short story author, and novelist. While studying in Paris at the Sorbonne, he published his first poem and a novel, "Lúcio's Confession," in 1914. He was one of the great exponents of modernism in Portugal and one of the most reputed members of the "Geração d'Orpheu" group responsible for the introduction of modernism in Portuguese arts and letters. A complex person, he came to financial ruin, had abandoned his studies, and had a recent quarrel with his father. A sufferer of depression and melancholy most of his life, he committed suicide by ingesting five bottles of arsenate and strychnine in Hôtel de Nice in the Parisian neighborhood of Montmartre. He was a close friend of Fernando Pessoa, one of Portugal's greatest poets. With Pessoa, he launched an avant-garde review periodical, "Orpheu" in 1915. He sent his unpublished poems to Pessoa, who published the pieces posthumously in 1937 under the title "Idicios de Oiro" or "Traces of Gold." A modern-style statue of him is located at Poets Park in Oeiras, Portugal.
